how_it_works.title: How WhatsMyName Works
how_it_works.subtitle: Using whatsmyname for username enumeration is simple and effective. Our whatsmyname app makes professional OSINT investigations accessible to everyone.

steps.title: Enter Target Username
steps.description: Input the username you want to investigate using our whatsmyname tool. The system accepts any alphanumeric username for comprehensive enumeration across 640+ platforms.

steps.title: Select Platform Categories
steps.description: Choose specific categories or search all 640+ platforms with whatsmyname. Focus on social media, professional networks, gaming platforms, or forums based on your investigation needs.

steps.title: Real-Time Enumeration
steps.description: Watch as the whatsmyname engine scans platforms in real-time. Results appear instantly with 94% accuracy, showing exactly where the username exists online.

steps.title: Export Evidence
steps.description: Download your whatsmyname results in multiple formats including CSV for analysis. Our tool provides detailed insights suitable for professional OSINT investigations.

faq.name: faq
faq.label: FAQ
faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Everything you need to know about WhatsMyName and how to use our whatsmyname tool effectively for professional OSINT investigations.
faq.description: Get answers to common questions about the whatsmyname tool and how to use it effectively for username enumeration and OSINT investigations.

items.title: What is WhatsMyName and how does the whatsmyname tool work?
items.description: WhatsMyName is a comprehensive username enumeration tool that searches over 640 platforms to find where usernames exist. Simply enter a username, and our advanced whatsmyname technology scans the internet to show digital footprints across different platforms with 94% accuracy.

items.title: How is the whatsmyname tool different from commercial alternatives?
items.description: While commercial tools focus on basic username availability, the whatsmyname tool provides real-time results, covers 640+ platforms, offers detailed analytics, and delivers superior performance. Our open-source whatsmyname system is more comprehensive and trusted by OSINT professionals worldwide.

items.title: Is the whatsmyname tool completely free to use?
items.description: Yes! WhatsMyName is completely free and open source. You can perform unlimited username enumerations across all 640+ platforms without any cost. The whatsmyname tool is maintained by the community and will always remain free for everyone.

items.title: Which platforms does the whatsmyname tool cover?
items.description: The whatsmyname tool covers major social networks (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, LinkedIn, TikTok), professional sites, gaming platforms, forums, and specialized websites. We continuously update our whatsmyname database to include new platforms and ensure comprehensive coverage.

items.title: How accurate are whatsmyname enumeration results?
items.description: The whatsmyname tool maintains 94% accuracy by using advanced detection methods and real-time verification. We regularly update our algorithms to ensure reliable results across all platforms in our database, making it trusted by security professionals.

items.title: Can I use the whatsmyname tool on mobile devices?
items.description: While we don't have a dedicated whatsmyname app, our web-based tool is fully responsive and works perfectly on mobile devices. You can access all whatsmyname features from your smartphone or tablet browser for field investigations.

items.title: Is my data private when using the whatsmyname tool?
items.description: Absolutely! The whatsmyname system doesn't store your search queries or personal information. All username enumerations are processed securely and privately. We prioritize user privacy and don't track or save your search history, making it perfect for sensitive OSINT work.

items.title: What if the whatsmyname tool shows conflicting results?
items.description: If you encounter conflicting results with the whatsmyname tool, it's usually due to platform-specific restrictions or privacy settings. We recommend manually verifying suspicious results, as some platforms may have changed their detection methods since the last whatsmyname update.
